description: From Middle English myschef, meschef, meschief, mischef, from Old French meschief, from meschever (“to bring to grief”), from mes- (“badly”) + chever (“happen; come to a head”), from Vulgar Latin *capare, from Latin caput (“head”).

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Conduct that playfully causes petty annoyance.
examples: Synonyms: delinquency, naughtiness, roguery, scampishness; see also Thesaurus:villainy, Thesaurus:mischief
John's mischief, tying his shoelaces together, irked George at first.

entries.meaning: (collective) A group or a pack of rats.
(uncountable) Harm or trouble caused by an agent or brought about by a particular cause.
examples: She had mischief in her heart.
Sooner or later he'll succeed in doing some serious mischief.

entries.meaning: (countable) An injury or an instance of harm or trouble caused by a person or other agent or cause.
examples: It may end in her doing a great mischief to herself—and perhaps to others too.

entries.meaning: (law) A criminal offence defined in various ways in various jurisdictions, sometimes including causing damage to another's property.
(archaic, countable) A cause or agent of annoyance, harm or injury, especially a person who causes mischief.
examples: Synonyms: bad boy, knave, rapscallion, rascal, rogue; see also Thesaurus:villain, Thesaurus:troublemaker

entries.meaning: (euphemistic) The Devil; used as an expletive.
examples: What the mischief are you? and how the mischief did you get here, and where in thunder did you come from?

verbs.description: mischief (third-person singular simple present mischiefs, present participle mischiefing, simple past and past participle mischiefed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To do a mischief to; to harm.
examples: […]  so, when the two ladders were taken down, no man living could come down to me without mischiefing himself,  […]
And so it hath been divers times; Men mischiefing the Jews to excuse their own Wickedness: as to instance one Precedent in the time of a certain King of Portugal.
